content: @WG-prioritization I'm starting this topic to discuss a bit about ideas on how to move P-high issues forward
we've been clearly making some progress related to this things, in particular, P-critical issues are clearly tracked and always fixes but I'm not sure how true is that for P-high
closing all the existing P-high issues that we have now may seem something impossible but if we slowly try to think about ideas to make progress we may reduce them a lot
as a first idea that I can think of is maybe taking some small amount of issues per week, like 4, and make a nice review of those and try to see how/who can fix them or something like that
but please share more ideas :)
i'm open to that
we could track the progress and check if anything is required

DPC said:

i'm open to that

you're :+1:ing my idea? :)

DPC said:

we could track the progress and check if anything is required

I was wondering how to do that exactly, I guess we could even add a temporary label so we tag all the ones that are reviewed and once we finish we just kill the label

we could chase 2 birds :bird: here:. Currently there is no way to know that a pr solves a P-critical / p-high issue without checking the issue. So if we could use the label for both it would be handy :P
Would applying "status labels" akin to the ones we have for PRs make any sense?
I'm thinking maybe we could take inspiration on what the Triage WG is currently doing for PRs
But for high priority bugs in our case
So I'm thinking maybe needs-assignee, has-assignee, has-pr? But I'm not convinced this is a good idea
can we automatically drop these labels after the relevant PR has been closed?
i think we already talked about this, but I have forgotten the result :sweat_smile:

lcnr said:

can we automatically drop these labels after the relevant PR has been closed?

We talked about that for a has-pr label and we said that it would be hard IIRC

But I think that as we are operating on a relatively small sample of issues, managing all by hand doesn't seem too hard to me, compared to the triage folks who have to manage 200+ open PRs? @DPC what would be your opinion on this?
by assignee you mean issue assignee ?
Yeah, which should be a compiler expert in most cases
since we are only triaging p-high & p-critical, i guess we could go through the list and see if they have a pr or not
Right, that's also what I thought
I think we may want to design an ideal procedure on how to deal with high priority issues forward
And from there see if what we can automatize and if what we cannot automatize is doable
ideally something that can filter out issues with no prs would be handy (not just here but beyond this wg) since there is no effective way of doing it in github
That seems like a problem that GitHub should fix, right? I'm not sure that we can do much about it, unfortunately.
